prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PSS J2322+1944
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To spatially resolve CO(10-9) emission in PSS J2322+1944.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We can observe CO(10-9) and a couple of H2O lines simultaneously, as these H2O lines are happened redshifted to the spectra windows close to CO(10-9). The CO line width (FWHM) of J2322+1944 is ~300 km/s, we will further smooth the channel width to 50 km/s.

We expect to resolve the CO(10-9) emission in J2322+1944. The linear scale of 1 arcsec is 7.0 kpc for J2322+1944, and available mid-J CO detections show that this galaxy extend to a few kpc. Assuming that the dense gas traced by CO(10-9) is concentrated in nuclear 1 arcsec region, we request an angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec for resolving and set the largest angular scale as 3.0 arcsec.

The expected CO(10-9) line peak flux density of J2322+1944 is 18.0 mJy. We request an angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec to ensure the CO(10-9) emission to be spatially resolved (resolve into ~5 beams). To detect this source at S/N~6, we need to reach an RMS of 0.6 mJy/beam. The CO line width (FWHM) of J2322+1944 is ~300 km/s, and we use a bandwidth of 50 km/s for sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ID 141
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To spatially resolve CO(10-9) emission in ID 141.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We can observe CO(10-9) and a couple of H2O lines simultaneously, as these H2O lines are happened redshifted to the spectra windows close to CO(10-9). The CO line width (FWHM) of ID 141 is ~800 km/s, we will further smooth the channel width to 100 km/s.

We expect to resolve the CO(10-9) emission in ID 141. The linear scale of 1 arcsec is 6.9 kpc for ID 141, and available mid-J CO detections show that this galaxy extend to a few kpc. Assuming that the dense gas traced by CO(10-9) is concentrated in nuclear 1 arcsec region, we request an angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec for resolving and set the largest angular scale as 3.0 arcsec.

The expected CO(10-9) line peak flux density of ID 141 is 8 mJy. We request an angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec to ensure the CO(10-9) emission to be spatially resolved (resolve into ~5 beams). To detect this source at S/N~6, we need to reach an RMS of 0.26 mJy/beam. The CO line width (FWHM) of ID 141 is ~800 km/s, and we use a bandwidth of 100 km/s for sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: BRI 1335-0417
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To spatially resolve CO(10-9) emission in BRI 1335-0417.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We can observe CO(10-9) and a couple of H2O lines simultaneously, as these H2O lines are happened redshifted to the spectra windows close to CO(10-9). The CO line width (FWHM) of BRI 1335-0417 is ~420 km/s, we will further smooth the channel width to 60 km/s.

We expect to resolve the CO(10-9) emission in BRI 1335-0417. The linear scale of 1 arcsec is 6.8 kpc for BRI 1335-0417, and available mid-J CO detections show that this galaxy extend to a few kpc. Assuming that the dense gas traced by CO(10-9) is concentrated in nuclear 1 arcsec region, we request an angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec for resolving and set the largest angular scale as 3.0 arcsec.

The expected CO(10-9) line peak flux density of BRI 1335-0417 is 9.0 mJy. We request an angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec to ensure the CO(10-9) emission to be spatially resolved (resolve into ~5 beams). To detect this source at S/N~6, we need to reach an RMS of 0.3 mJy/beam. The CO line width (FWHM) of BRI 1335-0417 is ~420 km/s, and we use a bandwidth of 60 km/s for sensitivity calculation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J1319+0950
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To detect CO(10-9) emission in J1319+0950.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The CO line width (FWHM) of J1319+0950 is ~540 km/s, we will further smooth the channel width to 100 km/s.
We expect to detect the CO(10-9) emission in J1319+0950. We request an angular resolution of 0.5 arcsec and set the largest angular scale to 3.0 arcsec.

The expected CO(10-9) line peak flux density of J1319+0950 is 0.8 mJy. We will observe this galaxy for CO(10-9) detection. To detect this source at S/N~4, we need to reach an RMS of 0.2 mJy/beam. The CO line width (FWHM) of J1319+0950 is ~540 km/s, and we use a bandwidth of 100 km/s for sensitivity calculation.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The widely used star formation (SF) law invokes the molecular gas tracers that rely on a single molecular line, in most cases CO(1-0). We have demonstrated that this will not really produce a unique SF law (LGG15). Moreover, these tracers are not necessarily proportional to the H2 gas mass owing to the uncertain CO-to-H2 conversion factors. In the AlMA era, through multiple molecular lines and with multiple-J rotational transitions, together with modeling efforts, we will be able to better address this fundamental issue of SF law by combining all observations to derive star-forming gas properties and resolve the disputes. Large uncertainties may exist at high-z, particularly because of the use of heterogeneous CO rotation lines in various studies at different redshifts. We here aim at CO(10-9) imaging at z>4, in 4 CO-strong SMGs/QSOs as an example, to illustrate the spatially resolved SF law in dense gas beyond the cosmic peak SF epoch. The linear SFR-CO(10-9) relation is valid in local galaxies and Galactic YSOs, and its confirmation at z>4 should dramatically improve our understanding of SF law and gain further physical insights to these high-z galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics and Astronomy, Edinburgh , University of
